''[[Torchwood]]'' | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/sja/ }} '''''The Sarah Jane Adventures''''' is a [[British television science fiction|British science fiction television]] series, produced by [[BBC Cymru Wales]] for [[CBBC]], created by [[Russell T Davies]] and starring [[Elisabeth Sladen]]. The programme is a spin-off of the long-running [[BBC]] [[science fiction on television|science fiction programme]] ''[[Doctor Who]]'' and focuses on the adventures of [[Sarah Jane Smith]], a middle-aged investigative journalist who, in her youth, had numerous adventures across time and space. The series debuted on [[BBC One]] with a 60-minute special, entitled "[[Invasion of the Bane]]", on 1 January 2007. A full series of ten 25-minute episodes followed, beginning on 24 September 2007.{{cite journal |date=8 November 2006 (cover date) |title=Sarah's Adventures |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=375|page=4}}
{{cite press release | title = Programme Information Network TV Week 39 |publisher=BBC | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/proginfo/tv/wk39/mon.shtml#mon_slitheen | accessdate = 7 September 2007 }} The first series consisted of five two-part stories,{{cite journal |date=3 January 2007 (cover date) |title=TV Preview: The Sarah Jane Adventures |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |first=Benjamin |last=Cook |issue=377 |page=27}} and a second series, comprising six two-part stories, began airing on 29 September 2008.{{cite press release | title = CBBC unveils new dramas | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/02_february/06/cbbc.shtml |publisher=BBC | date = 6 February 2008 | accessdate = 6 February 2008}}{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/09_september/09/sarahjane4.shtml | title = The Sarah Jane Adventures series two â broadcast details | accessdate = 10 September 2008 |work=BBC Press Office |publisher=BBC | date = 9 September 2008}} A third series, once again comprising six two-part stories to make a total of twelve episodes, with Russell T Davies serving as executive producer, aired from 15 October 2009{{cite web |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2008/nov/25/doctor-who-sarah-jane-adventures |title=BBC signs up for more of Doctor Who spin-off The Sarah Jane Adventures |accessdate=25 November 2008 |last=Dowell |first=Ben |coauthors= |date=25 November 2008 |work=The Guardian |location=UK |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited }}
{{cite press release |title= Distinctive, high quality, original, with the best known kids talent and made in the UK â the Winter/Spring Season from CBeebies and CBBC across TV, radio and online|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2008/11_november/25/childrens.shtml |publisher=BBC Press Office |date=25 November 2008 |accessdate=25 November 2008}} to 20 November 2009. The fourth series aired from 11 October 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/television/586307/new_promo_pic_for_the_sarah_jane_adventures_series_4.html |title=New promo pic for The Sarah Jane Adventures series 4 |publisher=Den of Geek |date=6 September 2010 |accessdate=9 May 2011}} Another spin-off series, ''[[Sarah Jane's Alien Files]]'', was shown concurrently with each of the first episodes of the stories.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/09_september/30/sja.shtml |title=Press Office â The Sarah Jane Adventures press pack: introduction |publisher=BBC |date=30 September 2010 |accessdate=9 May 2011}} Filming for three of six two-part serials planned for the fifth series was completed prior to [[Elisabeth Sladen]]'s death on 19 April 2011. Although some UK media, including the ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|Sun]]'', reported in early May 2011 that production of the series was to continue,{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/3561606/The-Sarah-Jane-show-must-go-on.html |title=Sarah Jane: The Show Must Go On |accessdate=4 May 2010 |last=Robertson |first=Colin |coauthors= |date=4 May 2011 |work=The Sun |location=UK |publisher=The Sun }} the BBC has stated explicitly that no further episodes will be filmed.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/dw/news/bulletin_110504_03/The_Sarah_Jane_Adventures |title=The Sarah Jane Adventures, 4 May 2011 |publisher=BBC website |date=4 May 2011 |accessdate=4 May 2011}} The fifth series was broadcast starting 3 October 2011 on Mondays and Tuesdays.{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorwhonews.net/2011/09/dwn150911152516-sarah-jane-adventures.html |title=Sarah Jane Adventures Series 5 - UK Air Date |publisher=Doctor Who News Page |accessdate=15 September 2011}} It finished just two weeks later on 18 October 2011. ''The Sarah Jane Adventures'' was nominated for a [[British Academy Children's Award]] in 2008 in the Drama category, and once again in 2009 for a [[BAFTA Cymru]], in Children's Drama.{{cite web |url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/childrens/nominations-childrens-awards-in-2008,593,BA.html |title=Children's Award Nominees |accessdate=29 October 2008 |date=28 October 2008 |publisher=[[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] }}{{cite web |title= 2009 Nominations: 18th Film, Television & Interactive Media Awards |url=http://www.bafta-cymru.org.uk/english/awards/pdf/2009_Final_Shortlist.pdf |publisher=[[Bafta Cymru]] |location=[[Cardiff]] |page=2 |format=PDF |date=16 April 2009 |accessdate=27 April 2009}} The programme won a [[Royal Television Society]] 2010 award for Best Children's Drama.{{cite web| url=http://www.rts.org.uk/winners-rpa | title= Programme Awards 2010: Winners | publisher=[[Royal Television Society]] website | date=15 March 2011 | accessdate=15 March 2011 }} ==Background and development== In 2006, Children's BBC expressed an interest in producing a ''Doctor Who'' spin-off. Their initial idea was "a drama based on the idea of a young ''Doctor Who''", but Russell T Davies vetoed this. "Somehow, the idea of a fourteen-year-old [[Doctor (Doctor Who)|Doctor]], on [[Gallifrey]] inventing [[sonic screwdriver]]s, takes away from the mystery and intrigue of who he is and where he came from," said Davies. He suggested instead a series based on the Doctor's former [[companion (Doctor Who)|companion]] Sarah Jane Smith.{{cite book |last=Russell |first=Gary |authorlink=Gary Russell |title=Doctor Who:The Inside Story |year=2006 |publisher=[[BBC Books]] |location=London |isbn=0-563-48649-X |page=252}} The character of Sarah Jane Smith, played by Sladen, appeared in ''Doctor Who'' from 1973 to 1976, alongside [[Jon Pertwee]] as the [[Third Doctor]] and later [[Tom Baker]] as the [[Fourth Doctor]]. A pilot episode for another ''Doctor Who'' spin-off series, ''[[K-9 and Company]]'', made in 1981, featured Sarah Jane and the robot dog [[K-9 (Doctor Who)|K-9]]; however, a full series was never commissioned. Sarah Jane and K-9 returned to ''Doctor Who'' in various media many times over the years, most notably in the 20th anniversary special ''[[The Five Doctors]]'' (1983), and in episodes "[[School Reunion (Doctor Who)|School Reunion]]" (2006), "[[The Stolen Earth]]" (2008), "[[Journey's End (Doctor Who)|Journey's End]]" (2008) and ''[[The End of Time]]'' (2010). Sarah Jane is frequently voted the most popular ''Doctor Who'' companion by both ''Doctor Who'' fans and members of the general public.{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/norfolk/content/articles/2006/04/19/film_doctor_who_lis_sladen_interview_feature.shtml | title = Doctor Who: Elisabeth Sladen talks | accessdate = 2 August 2006 | date = 7 July 2006 |publisher=BBC }} The prospect of a new television series focusing on Sarah Jane was first rumoured in ''[[The Sun (newspaper)|The Sun]]'' in March 2006, prior to the airing of "School Reunion"; the report at that time suggested that Sarah Jane and K-9 would both appear in the series.{{cite news |first = Sara |last = Nathan |url = http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2001320029-2006100483,00.html |title = Dr Who's K9 gets a lead |work=The Sun |location=UK |date = 4 March 2006 |accessdate = 2 August 2006 }} The fact that a Sarah Jane series was being developed was first confirmed in the BBC's in-house newsletter, ''Ariel'', in early August 2006.{{cite web | url = http://www.gallifreyone.com/cgi-bin/viewnews.cgi?id=EEVuulAZVpWNmQlQFw&tmpl=newsrss | title = Sarah Jane Investigates | author=Lyon, Shaun | date = 1 August 2006 | work=[[Outpost Gallifrey]] News Page | accessdate = 2 August 2006 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.thestage.co.uk/tvtoday/2006/08/with_apologies.php | title = With apologies... | accessdate = 6 August 2006 | last = Wright | first = Mark | authorlink = Mark Wright (writer) | date = 2 August 2006 | work=[[The Stage]] }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite journal | date = 13 September 2006 cover date | title = SARAH JANE INVESTIGATES! | journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] | issue = 373 | page = 5 }} These early rumours were associated with the working title ''Sarah Jane Investigates''. K-9's only appearances in the show's first two series were a cameo in the special and an appearance in the last episode of the first series.{{cite press release | title =Russell T Davies creates new series for CBBC, starring Doctor Who's Sarah Jane Smith |publisher=BBC | date =14 September 2006 | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2006/09_september/14/sarah.shtml | accessdate = 14 September 2006 }} This was due to the concurrent development of the independently produced children's series, ''[[K-9 (TV series)|K-9]]'', which features a remodelled version of K-9 with only indirect nods to ''Doctor Who''.{{cite news |first = Joe |last = Nazzaro |title = ''Who'''s Sarah Jane Gets Own Show |url = http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=1&id=38387 |work=[[Sci Fi Wire]] |publisher=[[Sci Fi Channel (United States)|Sci Fi Channel]] |date = 28 September 2006 |accessdate = 28 September 2006 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20061014071017/http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=1&id=38387 |archivedate = 14 October 2006}} However, in 2009 the canine robot appeared with the ''Sarah Jane Adventures'' cast in a [[From Raxacoricofallapatorius with Love|sketch]] for ''[[Comic Relief]]'', and K-9 appeared in 6 episodes of the third series.{{cite journal |last=Spilsbury |first=Tom, ed. |authorlink=Tom Spilsbury |date=1 April 2009 (cover date) |title=Ronnie meets K9 for a Comic Relief Special! |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=406 |page=6 }}
{{cite journal |last=Spilsbury |first=Tom, ed. |authorlink=Tom Spilsbury |date=4 March 2009 (cover date) |title=K9 is out of the safe and back in Sarah Jane's world â at last! |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=405 |page=12 }} ===Production=== Production on the full series began in April 2007.{{cite journal | date = 31 January 2007 (cover date) | first=Clayton | last=Hickman | authorlink=Clayton Hickman | coauthors=Spilsbury, Tom | title = Writing Sarah | journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] | issue = 378 | page = 5}} Two of the five two-part stories were scripted by the special's co-writer Gareth Roberts. It also screens in New Zealand on Nickelodeon New Zealand and in Belgium on KETNET. ==Cast and crew== [[File:Sarah Jane Adventures cast.jpg|thumb|The main cast of Series 1 (Left to right) [[Maria Jackson]], [[Luke Smith (The Sarah Jane Adventures)|Luke Smith]], [[Sarah Jane Smith]] and [[Clyde Langer]]]] In addition to Sladen, the first series of the programme stars [[Yasmin Paige]] as [[Maria Jackson]], Sarah Jane's 13-year-old neighbour (in [[Ealing]], London) and [[Tommy Knight]] as a boy named [[Luke Smith (The Sarah Jane Adventures)|Luke]], who is adopted by Sarah Jane at the conclusion of the introductory story. The third member of Sarah Jane's young entourage is 14-year-old called [[Clyde Langer]], played by [[Daniel Anthony (actor)|Daniel Anthony]], who is introduced in the first episode of the proper series. Porsha Lawrence Mavour plays Maria's friend, [[Kelsey Harper]], in the special.{{cite web | title =Sarah Jane's new companion | publisher=[[Outpost Gallifrey]] | date =2 March 2007 | url =http://www.gallifreyone.com/cgi-bin/viewnews.cgi?id=EEZlpAklEuNeJTaABW&tmpl=newsrss&style=feedstyle |accessdate = 23 March 2007}}
{{cite journal |date=27 June 2007 (cover date) |title=News Bites â Sarah's New Friend |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=383|page=5}} Maria and her family are written out of the series in the first story of the second series, ''[[The Last Sontaran]]'', but Maria and her father return briefly in the second part of ''[[The Mark of the Berserker]]''. In the second story of that series, ''[[The Day of the Clown]]'', several new regular cast members are introduced: [[Rani Chandra (The Sarah Jane Adventures)|Rani Chandra]] and her parents, [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Haresh Chandra|Haresh]], and [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Gita Chandra|Gita]] (played by [[Anjli Mohindra]], [[Ace Bhatti]], and [[Mina Anwar]], respectively).{{cite journal | title = Untitled section | journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] | issue = 395 | page = 12 | publisher=[[Panini Comics]] | date = 28 May 2008 (cover date)}} [[Joseph Millson]] appears throughout the first series as Maria's recently separated father, [[Alan Jackson (The Sarah Jane Adventures)|Alan]], with [[Chrissie Jackson]], Maria's mother, played by [[Juliet Cowan]]. One other regular is [[Alexander Armstrong (comedian)|Alexander Armstrong]] of comedy duo [[Armstrong and Miller (comedians)|Armstrong and Miller]], who provides the voice of [[Mr Smith (The Sarah Jane Adventures)|Mr Smith]], an extraterrestrial computer in Sarah Jane's attic. [[File:Bb160163@the-sarah-jane-adv.jpg|thumb|left|The main cast of Series 2â4. Clyde, Sarah Jane, Luke and [[Rani Chandra (The Sarah Jane Adventures)|Rani Chandra]].]] The 2007 special featured [[Samantha Bond]] as the scheming villain [[Mrs Wormwood]] and [[Jamie Davis]] as her PR agent [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Davey|Davey]]. The first series included among its guest cast [[Jane Asher]] as Sarah Jane's childhood friend [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Andrea Yates|Andrea Yates]], [[Floella Benjamin]] as [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Professor Rivers|Professor Rivers]], who returned in Series 2, Series 3 and Series 5, and [[Phyllida Law]] as [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Bea Nelson-Stanley|Bea Nelson-Stanley]]. The second series guest starred [[Bradley Walsh]] as an evil alien clown in the story ''[[The Day of the Clown]]'' and [[Russ Abbot]] as a sinister astrologer in ''[[Secrets of the Stars]]''. Also appearing in the second series were [[Gary Beadle]] and [[Jocelyn Jee Esien]], who portrayed Clyde's parents [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Paul Langer|Paul]] and [[List of The Sarah Jane Adventures minor characters#Carla Langer|Carla]] in ''[[The Mark of the Berserker]]''; Esien reprised her role briefly in Series 4 and more prominently in series 5. [[Nicholas Courtney]] guest starred in ''[[Enemy of the Bane]]'' as classic ''Doctor Who'' character Sir [[Alistair Lethbridge-Stewart]],{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Swift |title=Russell T. Davies explains why the Doctorâs not in the house |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article4824808.ece |work=The Times |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=29 October 2008}} and Samantha Bond also reprises her role as Wormwood for the episode. The original executive producers for ''The Sarah Jane Adventures'' were [[Phil Collinson]], Russell T Davies and [[Julie Gardner]]. [[Susie Liggat]] produced the pilot, but Matthew Bouch worked as producer of the series. Co-writer [[Gareth Roberts (writer)|Gareth Roberts]], writing in ''Doctor Who Magazine'', said, "We're all determined that this will be a big, full-blooded drama; that nobody should ever think of it as 'just' a children's programme."{{cite journal |first=Gareth |last=Roberts |authorlink=Gareth Roberts (writer) |date=8 November 2006 (cover date) |title=Production Notes |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue=375 |page=66}} Sue Nott was the executive producer of the second series for [[CBBC]]. In December 2007, the BBC released a statement that [[Julie Gardner]] would be replaced by [[Piers Wenger]] as Executive Producer for ''Doctor Who'' in January 2009, but that she would continue to executive-produce ''[[Torchwood]]'' and ''The Sarah Jane Adventures'' through 2008.{{cite press release | title = BBC Wales announces new Executive Producer of Doctor Who and Head of Drama | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2007/12_december/11/who.shtml |publisher=BBC | date = 11 December 2007 | accessdate = 11 December 2007}} The fourth series in 2010 was executive-produced by Russell T Davies and Nikki Wilson, and the producers were Brian Minchin and frequent writer Phil Ford. Several former companions of the Doctor are referenced in the story ''Death of the Doctor''. ==Episodes== {{Main|List of The Sarah Jane Adventures serials}} ''The Sarah Jane Adventures'' was first seen by its original British audience in the form of a 60-minute New Year's Day special in 2007, titled "[[Invasion of the Bane]]", which was co-written by Russell T Davies and Gareth Roberts. Though it may{{OR|date=October 2011}} have appeared so to the viewing audience, "Bane" was not a pilot. Instead, it was a [[List of Christmas Specials#Examples of British Christmas television special|holiday special]]. Nevertheless, because of the atypical broadcast order â holiday specials in Britain typically air ''after'' the regular run of the series to which they're attached â the story had many conventional introductory elements common to pilots. Creator Russell T Davies has commented upon the exceptional broadcast situation, saying "''Sarah Jane Adventures'' is slightly unusual in that it was commissioned before we'd written the script. If we'd written a load of rubbish, they'd still have had to make it." He refers to "Invasion of the Bane" simply as the "first episode".{{cite journal |date = 31 January 2007 (cover date) |first=Benjamin |last=Cook |authorlink=Benjamin Cook |title = Doing It for the Kids |journal=[[Doctor Who Magazine]] |issue = 378 |page = 37}} The story focused on Sarah Jane's investigation of a popular and addictive soft drink called ''Bubble Shock!''. Series one of the show aired in September of that year, consisting of five two-part half-hour stories. Individual half-hour episodes aired once a week on [[BBC One]], with episodes airing a week ahead on children's digital channel [[CBBC Channel|CBBC]]. The final part aired in November 2007. The second season started in September 2008 using the same format, with six stories instead of five, ending the season in December. The third season started 15 October 2009, twice weekly (Thursdays and Fridays) on BBC One from 15 October to 20 November.{{cite web|author=Monday, 28 September 2009, 7:02 pm EDT |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/cult/a176657/elisabeth-sladen-sarah-jane-adventures.html |title=Elisabeth Sladen ('Sarah Jane Adventures') â Sarah Jane Adventures Interview â British TV |publisher=Digital Spy |date=28 September 2009 |accessdate=9 May 2011}} Due to the illness of Elisabeth Sladen, and her subsequent death on 19 April 2011, filming for the second half of the fifth series, which was due to air in the autumn of 2011, was postponed and later cancelled.{{cite web|url=http://news.drwho-online.co.uk/Elizabeth-Sladen-RIP.aspx|title=Elizabeth Sladen RIP|publisher=Doctor Who Online|date=19 April 2011|accessdate=19 April 2011}} Filming for three stories of the fifth season had been completed.Chuck Foster, [http://www.doctorwhonews.net/2011/04/dwn190411204508-elisabeth-sladen-1948.html Elisabeth Sladen 1948â2011], Doctor Who News Page 19 April 2011, accessed 19 April 2011 The final series started to aired from 3 October to 18 October 2011 on CBBC and ended with a tribute to Elisabeth Sladen in the form of a video montage of scenes from SJA and Doctor Who.{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorwhonews.net/2011/09/dwn150911152516-sarah-jane-adventures.html|title=Sarah Jane Adventures Series 5 - UK Air Date|publisher=Doctor Who News Page|accessdate=15 September 2011}} ===Alien Files=== {{main|Sarah Jane's Alien Files}} ''Sarah Jane's Alien Files'' is a set of 25-minute episodes in which a member of the cast updates Mr. Smith's database about certain aliens. It accompanied series 4 of the programme. ==Critical response== ''The Sarah Jane Adventures'' has been generally well received by critics and the viewing public.{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Billen |title=Last night's TV |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/tv_and_radio/article2522908.ece |work=The Times |date=25 September 2007 |accessdate=29 October 2008}}
{{cite web |url=http://parenting.ivillage.com/familyentertainment_csm/tv/0,,cx5d77v0,00.html |title=The Sarah Jane Adventures Review - Television at ivillage.com |accessdate=29 October 2008 |author=Common Sense Media |publisher=[[ivillage.com]] }} At the end of the first series, a reviewer for ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' wrote: "With the debate about the future of childrenâs TV still rumbling on, this is what the BBC does best, and despite lacking the production values of ''Doctor Who'', itâs still top tea-time programming."{{cite news |first=Abi |last=Grant |title=Telegraph pick: The Sarah Jane Adventures (BBC1) |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/arts/main.jhtml?xml=/arts/exclusions/tvondemand/nosplit/LNoTV/bvsarah26.xml |work=Daily Telegraph |date=11 November 2007 |accessdate=29 October 2008}} In 2008, ''The Sarah Jane Adventures'' was nominated for a [[British Academy Children's Award]] (Children's BAFTA) in the Drama category. In 2009, the series was nominated for a [[BAFTA Cymru]] award in the Children's Drama category. The 2009 Comic Relief special achieved a rating of 8.3 million.[http://gallifreyone.com/news.php Red Nose Day â Ratings]{{dead link|date=May 2011}} ==Merchandising== Character Options have been awarded a licence to produce ''Sarah Jane Adventure'' play sets, [[action figure]]s, and a 'Sonic Lipstick' toy.{{cite press release | title = Licensees for Charlie and Lola, Sarah Jane | publisher=C21 Media | date = 30 January 2007 | url = http://www.c21media.net/news/detail.asp?area=79&article=34192 | accessdate = 30 January 2007 }} Four 2-figure sets have been released: Sarah Jane and Star Poet; Sarah Jane and General Kudlak; Sarah Jane and Child Slitheen and Sarah Jane and Graske. Also released are Sarah Jane's Sonic Lipstick with Watch Scanner and Alien Communicator. Character Options have now discontinued the range due to lack of customer interest.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} ===Audio adventures=== Eight audiobook have been released on CD, all read by series star Elisabeth Sladen. The first two were the first time that BBC Audiobooks had commissioned new content for exclusive release on audio.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/news/cult/news/drwho/2007/10/01/49352.shtml |title=The Sarah Jane Audios |accessdate = 2 October 2007 |work=BBC ''Doctor Who'' website }} All stories are read by Elisabeth Sladen in a first person perspective with Elisabeth reading in character as Sarah Jane Smith except for the last two, recorded after Sladen's death. A 20 Minute mini episode in two parts called "The Monster Hunt" written by [[Trevor Baxendale]], read by [[Anjli Mohindra]] this episode was made especially for the Monster Hunt game on the [[Sarah Jane Adventures]] website.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/sja/funandgames/monsterhunt/game/ |title=Monster Hunt |accessdate = 27 June 2011 |work=BBC ''Doctor Who'' website }} Both parts can only be downloaded by finding aliens around the [[Sarah Jane Adventures]] Website.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/sja/funandgames/monsterhunt/downloads/monster_hunt_pt1.mp3 |title=Monster Hunt |accessdate = 27 June 2011 |work=BBC ''Doctor Who'' website }}{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/sja/funandgames/monsterhunt/downloads/monster_hunt_pt2.mp3 |title=Monster Hunt |accessdate = 27 June 2011 |work=BBC ''Doctor Who'' website }} The November 2011 releases were read by Daniel Anthony and Anjili Mohindra after the death of Elisabeth Sladen.
